Chinese Traditional Medicine (CTM) for Diabetes.

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎05-27-2013 03:58 AM

 

Chinese Traditional Medicine (CTM) for Diabetes.

 

I have been for the last 10 months in China, so reading some stuff about Chinese Traditional Medicine and other alternative treatments online, all I can say there are a lot of quacks out there. But since I am in China, I decided I might as well try it. I went to the Lanzhou University Chinese Traditional Medicinal Hospital. Visited a doctor specialized in diabetes, so for CTM, this is about as good as it gets.

 

For background, I am 52, male, take Metformin 2000 mg, Januvia 100 mg and Crestor 10 mg each day, morning glucose between 80-110, BMI 22-23. Diagnosed Type 2, May 2012. I have good control, but I eat very low carb.

 

Chinese Traditional Hospital visit.

  1. No appointments or referrals. You just go to the hospital, sit and wait until the specialist sees you.
  2. Swipe ID card is used for all billing, doctor and test records and pharmacy orders. An integrated online computer system, they are way ahead of the US.
  3. No privacy. Open office door, other doctors, nurses, patients, relatives, come in and listen to what is going on.
  4. The hospital smells like the spice area of Whole Foods.

The doctor asked for medication that I am taking, looked at my glucose readings, took my pulse on both hands and checked my tongue. Gave me a prescription for 16 different herbs that I should take twice a day for 7 days. Then come back and he will adjust the herb mixture. And I should check my tongue, it is too white and thick, should get redder and thinner.

 

Total fee, $1 for the ID card, $5 for 7 day medicine supply, doctor $0. There are some big advantages to the socialist, or in this case communist, health care system.

But after 1 week, no differences in glucose readings that I can detect.

 

The second visit, I got 13 herbs, once daily, mostly different from the first 16. Second visit, total cost $8 for 14 day medicine supply.

 

Again, no significant difference in glucose reading. I do have the impression that, sometimes after drinking it, the next glucose reading is 10-20 point lower, but the two readings after that seem higher.  But looking at all the glucose readings, nothing significant that I can see. Either way, any effect is not consistent, and since I am not eating or exercising exactly the same, it is hard to really detect an effect.

 

In total, clear is, at best, a small and unpredictable effect of Chinese Traditional Medicine.  And CTM taste really bad, very bitter. So, stick with the regular medication, nothing to gain by adding CTM.

 

Cheers, Jean.

Metformin 2000mg
Januvia 100mg
Lipitor 20 mg
Aspirin 80mg

1/1/2013 5.1
7/10/2013 5.4
9/1/2013 5.2
11/1/2013 5.7
1/2/2014 5.6
3/5/2014 5.0
5/2/2014 5.6
8/6/2014 4.9

‎05-27-2013 04:54 AM - edited ‎05-27-2013 04:56 AM

Thank you for your very interesting report.

 

I wandered through several giant traditional medical centres in Suzhou and Beijing. Apart from the cubicles where the doctors saw patients they seemed like giant herbal (and other substances) warehouses. I had a cold when I arrived in Beijing but I wasn't as brave as you. I copied the characters for pseudoephedrine from a translation web-site and found a pharmacy 

 

My main diabetes control technique in China was avoiding excessive noodle and rice consumption.

 

What part of China are you in?

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.

‎05-27-2013 01:46 PM

Unless one is aware of drug/herb interactions, the contraindiction of mixing unknown herbs with current medications, IMO, is unadvisable.




Medicinal Induced T2'er since 2004
2.5 mg Glipizide
1.5 mg Prograf

5 feet 7 inches, 136-141 lbs
04/13 - Fasting/A1c 133/6.3 [aiming for 5.4%]

‎05-27-2013 02:08 PM

There are some good things to be said about CTM, such as acupuncture and yoga.  In many ways it's also a culture approach as well as a medical modality.

 

Herbal blends are a big part of the treatment.  One thing that I like about Chinese blends is that if one substance causes a side affect another is included in the blend to counteract or eliminate it.  This is the traditional way.  Also, as in our medicine, one or two visits is usually not enough to find the right mixture, it takes time. 

 

I studied CTM for quite some time, but since this is not my culture and most western medicine does not practice it, I decided to stick to what was known and practiced in my culture.

 

Another thing I really liked about the traditional CTM way was that you didn't pay if you got sick, only if you stayed well.  Can you see the West doing that?  

 

Lizzy

Knowledge is Power!

knops1 wrote:

 

There are some big advantages to the socialist, or in this case communist, health care system.

 

Inserted comment by George_M:  It would seem that the biggest differences are these:

 

But after 1 week, no differences in glucose readings that I can detect.

 

The second visit, I got 13 herbs, once daily, mostly different from the first 16. Second visit, total cost $8 for 14 day medicine supply.

In total, clear is, at best, a small and unpredictable effect of Chinese Traditional Medicine.  And CTM taste really bad, very bitter. So, stick with the regular medication, nothing to gain by adding CTM.

 

Thanks for the report.  It is always interesting to try something off the beaten path and see what happens.  I am not closed-minded enough to think that Western medicine has a monopoly on medical knowledge, but I am not open-minded enough to think that all the real secrets of medicine reside in the centuries-old traditions of other cultures.  I like to have real-world reports like yours.

 

Chinese medicine offers medical care (of sorts) to the Chinese people at low cost, but in my opinion it may be worth about what they pay for it.  I do note that whenever the tinpot dictator of some banana republic gets seriously ill, he comes to the U.S. for treatment.  I guess the exception was Hugo Chavez.  Our medical system is not perfect, but neither is anybody else's.

George

Diagnosed T2 9/12/12, A1C 10.1
Metformin 500 mg. 1 x daily since 9/17/2012
A1C 12/13/2012 5.6
A1C 3/15/2013 5.4
A1C 11/29/2013 5.5

‎05-27-2013 06:09 PM

Alan; Lanzhou, Gansu Province, in the Northwest of China. And yes avoiding noodles and rice helps. The worse is steamed white bread, even a little spikes me really high.

 

Porkee; interactions, yes good point. I test a lot and have not seen any spikes. However, also note I did this under supervision of a Chinese University doctor trained in CTM, with weekly visits. And herbs are plants and here in China I don’t know ½ the ingredients in the food that I am eating.

 

Lizzylou; sorry I have to disagree with you. Yes yoga is good as it relaxes you and lower stress is good for many things. Acupuncture, herbs, homeopathy are useless, there is no credible evidence showing this. However, believers do get a placebo effect, so if it works for believers, great, keep doing it. Here in China, I have noticed that CTM, including acupuncture, is only used as a supplement to Western medication. So, China is actually using the placebo effect of CTM to complement Western medication, never to replace it. So I think all those quacks out there trying to make money of things like CTM are dishonest and misleading patients looking for some magically.

 

George_M: Yes, herbs contain chemicals, so I can see potential ways that they might work. But, as I said, no effect for me, however it is cheap. And we know that the placebo effect really can help people. So using CTM as a supplement to make people who believe it it, feel better, makes perfect sense. But since I don’t believe, it is useless for me.

Lizzylou; sorry I have to disagree with you. Yes yoga is good as it relaxes you and lower stress is good for many things. Acupuncture, herbs, homeopathy are useless, there is no credible evidence showing this. However, believers do get a placebo effect, so if it works for believers, great, keep doing it. So, China is actually using the placebo effect of CTM to complement Western medication, never to replace it. And I, in turn have to disagree with you.

 

Animals are not affected by the "placebo effect, and yet acupuncture is used by many vets now quite sucessfully on them.  And yes, there are studies.

 

I have also used both yoga and acupuncture very successfully myself, but it's too expensive to do on a regular basis. 

 

 

Your mind is pretty much closed, so I won't say any more on the subject.

 

Lizzy

Re: Chinese Traditional Medicine (CTM) for Diabetes.

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎05-28-2013 01:57 AM

Hi Lizzy,

 

Ok, let’s agree to disagree. But, I will give you my rationale here.

 

  1. Plants contain chemicals and some of them clearly have effects, think of metformin which is derived from French lilac and there is a recent treatment for malaria derived from a plant based on CTM. So, I don’t reject CTM outright, but I would like to see some real evidence before I add a bunch of chemicals to my body.
  2. The reasoning behind many alternative treatments, like CTM, acupuncture, homeopathy, faith healers, etc, conflicts with anything we know about chemistry, physics and biology. The same is the case for notions like witches, fairies, ghosts, the earth is flat, the sun goes around the earth, etc. It mystifies me why people believe in this clearly flawed reasoning.
  3. For CTM there are many specialized current journals and I have looked at a number of review articles in these journals and specific studies looking into diabetes. Up to about 5-15 years ago all the research was lousy, current reviews in these Chinese journals lament this and ignore most of earlier studies and more recent studies are getting much more robust. To summarize it, earlier work mostly used a cohort approach, you get 10 people (often a range from 5-10), treat all of them, and then examine the outcome of the people left after a period. The problem with this is, there is no control, nothing to compare it too. Secondly, only people enrolled until the end are used in the analysis, even people dying and getting much sicker and going into intensive care, were excluded. Both these issues make earlier studies pretty much useless. For acupuncture pretty much the same. I did see a number of recent acupuncture studies that used specific placement of the needles according to CTM, versus randomly sticking the same number of needles in patients. These studies showed no difference. So research is getting better, but much most of what you read in books, blogs, etc, is based on the older useless research.
  4. So, reread 1. Yes, I think that we will find new useful chemicals based on CTM. But currently there is no logical rational why it would work, no clear evidence that it does works, and potentially many side effects of unknown chemicals in unknown concentration that you consume. So, I would rather wait until the research catches up and we know what has a benefit.
  5. So, why did I try it? Well I keep talking to people that say, regardless of all the arguments above, I believe in it and it works for me, it is personalized medicine and you can’t apply Western scientific standards to it, and you are close minded, and not willing to consider alternatives.
  6. So, I tried it, and seeing no effect for me, I can clearly say it does not work for me. And I tried with a doctor specialized in diabetes care at a major CTM University Hospital in China, which is as good a CTM treatment as you can get. I would not have done this with any of the quacks doing this in the US. I posted this for anyone curious about CTM. But in the end, this is my opinion, it is a free world out there (at least outside of China), and anyone can spend their money anyway they want and do whatever they want.

Cheers, jean.

Metformin 2000mg
Januvia 100mg
Lipitor 20 mg
Aspirin 80mg

1/1/2013 5.1
7/10/2013 5.4
9/1/2013 5.2
11/1/2013 5.7
1/2/2014 5.6
3/5/2014 5.0
5/2/2014 5.6
8/6/2014 4.9
